data.title: Incompatible packages detection makes incorrect assumptions about directory structure
data.body:
In package.coffee ([here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/f4cfe7603fbe99c8f717eb92fdff20d33b3fd90a/src/package.coffee#L679 ) and [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/f4cfe7603fbe99c8f717eb92fdff20d33b3fd90a/src/package.coffee#L664)) we expect to find native modules at paths that look like `module_root/build/Release/module.node`. However, not all npm packages conform to this "standard": for those that don't, we are sometimes unable to locate the package.json of the npm package containing the native module in question.

This causes Atom to not be able to determine the incompatible npm package's version. Also, if a single npm package contains multiple incompatible native modules, we will report it multiple times.

/cc: @iolsen @ungb

data.title: distiguish soft-wrapped lines (=parts) from non-wrapped lines
data.body:
this is a mix between an issue and a feature request. ### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: ... ### Description There is no chance to distinguish a normal line from a part of a soft-wrapped line. Additionally I want to distinguish the first line and the last line from the other wrapped parts. I see these possibilities: * class `.line` could be the whole line including all continuation lines and the wrapped partial lines have a different class (something like `.wrapped-line`) ```
line beginning
line continuation
line continuation
``` * if this breaks too much, it could be the other way: the wrapped parts could be wrapped by a class `.soft-wrapped-line` ```
line beginning
line continuation
line end
``` * if this still breaks too much, it could be without the outer level: ```
line beginning
line continuation
line end
``` This would allow to make display of continuation lines more usable. E.g. currently you see indent markers etc. which is wrong IMHO while visible whitespace seems to be correct. I would add wrapping markers in front of continuation lines and also at the end of a line being wrapped. These are the points where you look while reading. Currently you have to look in the gutter instead which is not convenient. Here is an example (SciTE-Editor): ![continuation-lines](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4707597/25387860/7a7a2200-29cc-11e7-967b-2a7cfc8501f0.png) This would probably affect other issues like #14294

data.title: Beginning of line and end of line modifiers not working as expected when soft wrap is enabled
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

*note* - I am using Mac OSX but I believe these shortcuts are applicable on most OSes.

When soft wrap is enabled and a line wraps to the next line pressing `ctrl+shift+e` doesn't work as expected.

`ctrl+e` goes to the end of the line as expected. That is, it goes to the end of the ACTUAL line, not the end of the soft-wrapped line. This means the cursor may move a few rows downward.

`ctrl+shift+e` on the other hand stops at the end of the current row even if the line is soft wrapped to multiple lines. It also occasionally does not highlight the last character in that line.

Screenshot: ![](https://www.dropbox.com/s/kt675lvkrvlysjg/Screenshot%202017-04-24%2022.06.06.png?dl=0&raw=1)

On a similar note, if you go to any line beyond the first of a soft-wrapped line and press `ctrl+a` it only goes to the beginning of the soft wrapped line, not the actual line.

This behavior is unexpected because soft wrapping shouldn't affect what is or isn't a line. It is just tool to help visualize long lines easier. Unfortunately this isn't how it is behaving in Atom.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open up atom and turn on soft wrap (View -> Toggle Soft Wrap).
2. Write a line of text that soft wraps to the next line
3. Go to any position of the line in the first row and press `ctrl+shift+e`

or


1. Open up atom and turn on soft wrap (View -> Toggle Soft Wrap).
2. Write a line of text that soft wraps to the next line
3. Go to any position of the line in the second row and press `ctrl+a`

**Expected behavior:** I expect to go to the end of the actual line, not the soft-wrapped line when pressing `ctrl+shift+e`. I expect to go to the start of the actual line, not the soft-wrapped line, when pressing `ctrl+a`. These would both be inline with what happens when you press `ctrl+e` currently.

**Actual behavior:** My cursor moves near the end of the soft-wrapped line (and sometimes misses the last character on it oddly) when pressing `ctrl+shift+e` and there is a soft-wrap. Similarly if I am on any line but the first soft-wrapped line and press `ctrl+a` my cursor moves to the start of the current soft-wrapped line, not the start of the actual line.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom:

```
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

OS: Mac OS X El Capitan - 10.11.6

APM:

```
apm  1.16.1
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.10.1
```

### Additional Information

None

data.title: @lee-dohm - Atom as windows app is an opportunity for your software.
data.body:
@lee-dohm 
Hi! I'm Francesco Venuti and I founded UWP Open Source Community, dgsimone15 already contacted you about UWP, but you didn't seem to understand our intentions, so let me explain better ...
We are a team of Windows lovers and developers without any scope of make money. We would only improve our OS ... in the last year Windows 10 has improved a lot, for example today also incorporates a Linux Subsystem (WSL)... Now Microsoft also engaged the mobile challenge, it seems that they would change the concept of mobile computing ... so not just a smartphone, but real desktop experience that could run on ARM devices like tablets and smartphones (connected with a monitor).
We saw the preview of "Windows Colud Edition", this could be the next edition of Windows for education PC (like Chromebooks). Unfortunately for running win32 software on this edition, the software must be converted into UniversalWindowsPlatform app; after conversion, the software could run even on regular Windows 10 editions. If this could be a problem, you should consider the opportunities like: all UWP could use a telemetry to send information about problems to developer, guarantee automatic update every time you emprove your software, could impact on a larger and younger user base that can give You feedback and also start developing your software. 
Furthermore distributing your software as UWP mean that your software run in a sandbox that don't compromise the OS if there are problems.
We don't want make a copy of your work, rather we prefer YOU start publish also on Windows Store as alternative distribution to traditional installer.
We tried the online tool made by Microsoft for convert win32 software to UWP app, if you would use our work to start your experience on Microsoft Store we are pleased to give you all materials and information. Don't be scared about shadow costs, for publish on Microsoft Store you pay only the first time as developer registration, because your app will FLOSS, so there are not fee!
For us is important start Windows Cloud with a large amount of open source apps available for every one.
Scuse me for poor English...😉

data.title: Win10 Jump Lists do not respect "Run as Administrator"
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

On Windows 10, recently opened files and projects are added to a Jump List. However, I have my atom shortcut configured to always Run as Administrator (due to stupid *$#!#$!!! Windows 10/IIS permissions). Unfortunately, none of the items in the Jump List launch as administrator. This renders the Jump List/Recent Items feature useless: I can't save any files when Atom is running with reduced permissions.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Configure Atom to Run as administrator
    1. Launch Atom
    1. Pin Atom to taskbar
    1. Close Atom
    1. Right click on the Atom shortcut in the taskbar to bring up the context menu.
    1. Right click on Atom in the context menu to bring up the child context menu (thanks, Microsoft!)
    1. Click on Properties
    1. In the Shortcut tab, click Advanced
    1. Check the "Run as administrator" checkbox. 
    1. Press OK to close Advanced Properties. Press OK to close Properties.
1. Click the shortcut in the taskbar to launch Atom. Atom launches as Administrator.
1. Run the Application: Open Folder command (Ctrl+Shift+O by default) and open `C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc`
1. Open the `hosts` file, add some whitespace, Ctrl+S to save.
1. Close Atom.
1. Right click the Atom shortcut in the taskbar and click the `etc` Project.
1. Open the `hosts` file, delete the whitespace that was previously added, and save the file. 

**Expected behavior:** 

Changes to the `hosts` file are saved because Atom was launched either (1) with the permissions in place when the recently used item was added to the list or (2) with the permissions defined in the taskbar shortcut.

**Actual behavior:** 

Changes to the `hosts` file fail to save with the error `EPERM: operation not permitted`

**Reproduces how often:** 

100%

### Versions

Windows 10 Pro (64-bit)

Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

data.title: a pane is not .active until a second pane exists
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

In atom 1.16.0 (stable) I created styles to improve visibility of
* active pane (e.g. background of tab-bar)
* active tab in active pane (e.g. background of tab)

I recently switched to atom 1.17.0-beta3.

Now the pane with the active editor tab does not become active after starting atom.

Instead tree view (which is in a tab now) is shown as the active tab in the active pane or no visible pane is active at all (I didn't find an active pane in developer tools either).

When clicking on an editor tab it's surrounding pane does not get active state.

When I drag one of the editor tabs to a new pane it gets the active state and the new pane is also active.

After creating the second pane all works like expected, even when I close the second pane.
So I assume it's an initialization problem, probably related to the tree view being a tab or some thing similar.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. create a style to conveniently see which is the active pane (and it's active tab):
```
.pane.active {
  .tab-bar {
    background-color: #ffff00 !important;
    .tab {
      &.active {
        background-color: #ff00ff !important;
      }
    }
  }
}
```
2. open some files in a single pane
3. close atom
4. open atom again
5. try to activate the editor pane
6. drag a file tab to a new pane

**Expected behavior:**

the editor pane should be active after start

**Actual behavior:**

Either the pane containing the tree view (left dock) is active or no pane is active at all (at least not visible).
The single editor pane cannot get active state by clicking on a tab or similar actions.

**Reproduces how often:**

100%

### Versions

atom-beta --version:
Atom    : 1.17.0-beta3
Electron: 1.3.14
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm-beta --version:
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.11.0

OS: Linux Debian "testing"
with some packages from unstable and Ubuntu and ppas etc.

note, I have atom and atom-beta installed in parallel, but they shouldn't interfere.

### Additional Information

not necessary but helpful:
a style (as described above) emphasizing the active pane and the active tab in the active pane.

data.title: I would like to have permission to publish your app on the Windows Store
data.body:
Hi, I'm part of the UWP Open Source Community (https://github.com/UWP-Open-Source-Community). Our intent is to take Win32 Open Source applications and convert them into UWP apps through the Windows Bridge (Project Centennial).
We like your app and that's why we decided to convert it.
In case you would like to take charge of this app and publish it yourself on the store (make us very pleased) contact us the first possible please! Otherwise, we may be responsible for publishing your app.
If you do not want to take over the publication on the Store, can you give us permission to do so?
Sorry for my poor English.
Thanks for your help.

data.title: Packages globally preload nondeterministically before updateProcessEnv configures process.env properly
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

updateProcessEnv MUST run before anything from ~/.atom because there are many, many packages which depend on the user's specific configuration, not the system-default configuration. This includes any community packages (maybe some built-in packages too, but not sure) from ~/.atom which may get preloaded. Basically, anything loading a community package has to synchronously await completion of `updateProcessEnv`.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Move/backup `~/.atom` out of the way.
1. Add `sleep 5; export HI=5` to the top of user's login shell script.
1. Put a debugging `console.log "updateProcessEnv ran here"` in `src/update-process-env.js` near the end of `updateProcessEnv`.
1. `~/.atom/init.coffee`: Put a debugging `console.log "HI=#{process.env.HI}"`.
1. Some random package in the exports file: Put a debugging `console.log "HI=#{process.env.HI}"`.
2. Rebuild and install atom.
3. Install a [crap-ton of packages](https://gist.github.com/steakknife/c621c0d56eeeb10265b2fb549112cf1b).
4. Restart atom NOT from the command-line and check the console a few times for `HI=...`.

**Expected behavior:**

Packages are always configured for user's login shell environment. (Always `HI=5`)

**Actual behavior:**

Breaks because it's configured to the system-default environment.

**Reproduces how often:**

85%

### Versions

f4a83b238 head (1.18.0-dev-f4a83b238)  & 1.16.0

### Additional Information

macOS

data.title: Fix bundled package path check to use path, not name

data.title: Find-file (cmd-p) in gargantuan repo experiences significant slowness
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When using atom with a gargantuan repo (in my case, all of Firefox: https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central), the fine-file dialog (cmd-p) experiences significant performance problems. It is generally not able to keep up with the speed at which I type, leading to confusion.

When I say doesn't keep up with the speed at which I type, I don't mean it can't search that fast, I mean that rendering the keys I'm typing is delayed, often for many seconds.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Be in a _massive_ repo
2. cmd-p
3. Start typing (for example in mozilla-central: SandboxPolicies)

**Expected behavior:** The letters I type are rendered instantly, even if the search can't be completed instantly

**Actual behavior:** The UI jerks around, the letters I type take multiple seconds to appear on the screen

**Reproduces how often:** Nearly always

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

macOS 10.12.4

data.title: Markdown syntax highlight glitches
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

An image is worth 1000 words:

![captura de pantalla de 2017-04-21 09-36-36](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/973709/25268007/60395d50-2677-11e7-80d2-b47cff0964fe.png)


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Write something similar to the image in a .md file.

**Expected behavior:** Highlighted sections:

1. Should be rendered as a link.
2. Should be rendered as code block.
3. Should be rendered as a bold link.

**Actual behavior:**

1. Links with newlines in between do not render as such.
2. Code blocks inside lists do not render as such.
3. Links inside bold text do not render as such.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
➤ atom --version
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

➤ apm --version
apm  1.16.1
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.9.3

➤ lsb_release -a
LSB Version:	:core-4.1-amd64:core-4.1-noarch
Distributor ID:	Fedora
Description:	Fedora release 25 (Twenty Five)
Release:	25
Codename:	TwentyFive
```

data.title: Dropping a tab in a new window's content area gets ignored
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The split-pane layout management feature doesn't work when dragging tabs to a new window.

In fact, dropping a tab anywhere outside the tab bar just gets ignored.  This is surprising because that's not how dragging works in the main window.

This is related to this excellent PR: https://github.com/atom/tabs/pull/252

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a project
2. Create a new window with `cmd-shift-N`
3. Drag a tab from the project to the window you just opened

**Expected behavior:** Ideally, you'd see the shaded regions allowing you to open a new pane left/right/top...  But I'd settle for a drop in the content area working.

**Actual behavior:** The drag is ignored.  You must hit the tab bar exactly for it to work.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

![bug3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1776/25256002/af8eb80e-25e2-11e7-9f14-9629488d2fce.gif)

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

MacOS Sierra

```
~$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
~$ apm --version
apm  1.16.1
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.9
git 2.2.1
```

data.title: Minor: "Find File" match highlighting does not prefer contiguous word matches
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Minor UI issue with the highlighting of matched text in the "Find File" feature.  While the ability to find files despite varying insertions around whitespace, underscores, etc. is *awesome*, when highlighting of matched strings in the paths displayed, there should still be a preference for matching the whole string.  

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have files in project, e.g.:
- `./app/views/hyrax/admin/appearances/show.html.erb`
- `./spec/controllers/hyrax/admin/appearances_controller_spec.rb`
- `./spec/views/hyrax/admin/appearances/show.html.erb_spec.rb`
- etc.
2. Find > Find File > "appearances"

**Expected behavior:** If the full string is matched in the pathname, it should be highlighted. In this case "appearances".  
**Actual behavior:** The "a" is highlighted from earlier in the path, and subsequently, only "ppearances" or "rances" is highlighted.  
**Reproduces how often:** Deterministic, every time.

![screen shot 2017-04-20 at 3 14 52 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/109954/25254964/3dd326aa-25dd-11e7-90ef-4b507f846758.png)


### Versions
```
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```
